Award.AwardTitle: Establish a NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center for Lasers & Plasmas for Advanced Manufacturing (LAM)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) in the area of Lasers and Plasmas for Advanced Manufacturing will develop a science, engineering and technology base for laser and plasma processing of materials, devices and systems. Laser and Plasma processing of materials is used in various manufacturing sectors such as semiconductor/electronic manufacturing, aerospace, automotive, general manufacturing, life science products, medical device manufacturing. The focus of the center includes: bulk processing, surface processing, coatings, surface etching and patterning.

The I/UCRC will also take full advantage of being cited next to Free Electron Laser Facility of Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility. The Facility is the world's most powerful, tunable laser, currently delivering kilowatt average power in the mid infrared. The strong interest in the center is evidenced from various letters of commitment received from industry and federal laboratories.

Institution.Name: University of Virginia Main Campus
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF funding was received to support the operation of the NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center for Lasers and Plasmas for
Advanced Manufacturing. The NSF provided seed funding while majority of funding was received from the Center industrial members. The Center Industrial Advisory Board selected the research projects carried out in the Center. The Center has become a multi-university center with participation by the University of Virginia, University of Michigan, University of Illinois and Southern Methodist University. The Center organizes two board meetings per year at participating university sites. NSF funds allowed the attendance of the Board meetings and partial support for two graduate students. Graduate students carried out research in the area of high power laser applications of interest to industrial advisory board members. Some of the projects that were carried out included: Laser micromachining, laser cladding, corrosion detection. The supported projects are of direct interest to industrial members.  

Lasers are increasingly used for advanced manufacturing in various industrial sectors such as automotive, aerospace, electronics, photovoltaics, biomedical and general manufacturing. NSF support allowed to make advances in the laser based manufacturing and provides a competitive edge
to U.S. industry. The NSF support also allowed the education of graduate students to meet the future work force needs.


Last Modified: 05/08/2012
Modified by: Mool C Gupta
